comment: Nice guy - can't teach. Relies heavily on the textbook and just writes exactly what is on the book, on the board w/o explaining why he is writing it. He makes mistakes often so there's times where I have to completely scribble out the notes I wrote because it was wrong. Although, he did allow for extensions on hw if asked. Tutoring will be needed!

Uses book 4 lecture & tho verbatim frm book, refuses 2make it electronic. As such, when writing on board, he doesn't say wut hes writing so is hrd 2 follow. Zero review. No such thing as partialcredit. Suggest you avoid unlss you have strong calculus understanding. He knows the subject well but makes mistakes in lecture becuz his handwritten notes.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: He was a cool guy but admittedly not the greatest teacher. He does want you to do well grades-wise though, he rounded my grade up and gave extensions on all the homework assignments.

Ephraim's class was a bit of a struggle to show up to. He read directly from the curriculum and wrote problems on the board. There was very little class-teacher interaction, and he didn't pay attention to the room at all during quizzes or tests. Most of my learning was done on Aleks.

He is a professor that knows what he is doing but doesn't teach it very well. What he teaches doesn't line up with the homework but he is more than willing to extend the homework modules if you ask. If you do all of the work online but don't make good grades on the test then you should be able to pass.

Tests are 50% of the grade and don't reflect the tons of homework. Provides zero online resources, and cannot answer questions in class. Attendance is required, and even short lectures seem like they last hours. You're allowed a notecard with formulas for tests, and he extends homework deadlines, but be prepared to rely on other sources.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Test heavy

comment: He basically just explained what formulas did but not why. I don't know how someone is supposed to learn a subject as complex as calc 3 without having at least some derivation. Unless you feel like you can teach yourself the subject or do math based purely off of a formula sheet, look for a different instructor.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Took Calc 3 with him, and tbh he was a pretty good prof. It was just a difficult course. I'd take him again, he grades pretty fairly and extends the hw due dates when needed, just be aware it is a LOT of hw. Just try to choose a class that isn't over 1hr and 20min long bc the lectures can definitely feel like drags

I took him Spring 2020. Tests were multiple choice which I did not like, but I would ask him so many questions, and he was so happy to respond back to me. I believe he is a good adjunct professor because I can tell he cares if you put in the effort. Just ask questions and do the homework, listen to the lectures, etc. He helps if it is needed!

This class was just not it, rushes through explanations, more definitions than solving, exams are tough no where near study guid and grades toughly, you will have to really study hard to pass this class 10% Homework, 75% for 3 tests and 15% for final exam. Absolutely no Extra Credit If you fail test 1 and 2 just withdraw to save your mental health.

He does not seem to understand you if you have problems with his explanations, and he rushes through his lectures. If you want to learn calculus this is not the class for you. You will have to teach yourself if you take this class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: He is a good professor if you want someone who will actually care if you pass. He emails you back any time of night. He extends assignments if you weren't able to complete it on time. Study for the test because they get more difficult.
